G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Pursuant to Massachusetts law, modifications of child custody and parenting time orders may be granted upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and where the modification serves the best interests of the child.

*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Pursuant to Massachusetts law, modifications of child custody and parenting time orders may be granted upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and where the modification serves the best interests of the child.
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns the standards governing an initial custody award in a divorce judgment, not modification of an existing custody or parenting-time order. While it clearly affirms that custody decisions must be based on the best interests/welfare of the child, it does not discuss, apply, or even mention the separate requirement of a material and substantial change in circumstances necessary for modification under Massachusetts law. Therefore it supports only part of the proposition (best interests) and not the modification/change-in-circumstances component, so it is not good authority for the full stated proposition.
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied)… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed.”

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: In evaluating the best interests of the child, Massachusetts courts consider several factors, including the child’s emotional needs, relationships with the parents, and the ability of each parent to provide a stable and nurturing environment. See *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985).
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly describes how Massachusetts courts evaluate the child’s best interests, including attention to the child’s quality of life, emotional and developmental needs, and the competing abilities and circumstances of each parent. In applying the “best interests” and “real advantage” standards, the court discusses the children’s relationships with each parent, the mother’s nurturing role and stability she can provide, and the impact of the move on the children’s emotional and developmental needs. This aligns with the proposition’s listed factors.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life), the possible adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent, and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”

*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: Moreover, the minor child's desire for greater time with her mother further supports that a modification would be in Sophie's best interests. See *Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012); *Rosenberg v. Merida*, 428 Mass. 182 (1998).
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: Hunter v. Rose discusses the best interests of the child in awarding primary physical custody, but the opinion does not mention Jill’s (the child’s) custodial preferences or treat the child’s stated desire to spend more time with a particular parent as a factor supporting modification. The court’s analysis focuses on parental conduct, stability, alienation, and ability to foster the child’s relationship with the other parent, not the child’s wishes. Therefore, it does not support the specific proposition that the minor child’s desire for greater time with her mother supports that a modification is in her best interests.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is]… what is ‘best for the child’…. However, the judge must weigh ‘all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child.’… Factors a judge may weigh are whether one parent’s home is more stable in terms of a parent’s work schedule, whether siblings are being raised together, and whether one parent seeks to undermine the relationship a child has with the other parent.” (463 Mass. at 494-95).

*Rosenberg v. Merida*, 428 Mass. 182 (19.proposition: Moreover, the minor child's desire for greater time with her mother further supports that a modification would be in Sophie's best interests. See *Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012); *Rosenberg v. Merida*, 428 Mass. 182 (1998).
*Rosenberg v. Merida*, 428 Mass. 182 (19.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns using a minor child’s stated desire for more time with a parent as support for a best-interests finding in a custody/parenting-time modification. Rosenberg v. Merida does not discuss the child’s preferences or the weight to be given to them in a best-interests analysis. Its custody discussion is limited to the inadequacy of findings supporting a change from shared to sole legal custody and contains no language about considering or relying on a child’s wishes, so it does not support the cited proposition.
*Rosenberg v. Merida*, 428 Mass. 182 (19.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, provides that a Probate and Family Court judge may modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody of a minor child on finding ‘that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the child[].’ … However, the judge ‘failed to make specific or detailed findings based on evidence within the record’ that awarding sole legal custody of the minor child to the defendant was in the best interests of the child.”

*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.proposition: Plaintiff also asserts that Defendant's unwillingness to cooperate in considering Sophie’s expressed wishes and therapeutic input is contrary to Sophie’s emotional well-being. See *Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981).
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a parent’s unwillingness to cooperate with the other parent in considering a child’s expressed wishes and therapeutic input as being contrary to the child’s emotional well-being. Rolde discusses joint custody, parental cooperation, and best interests of the child, but it does not address a parent’s refusal to consider the child’s expressed wishes or therapeutic input, nor frame such refusal as contrary to the child’s emotional well-being. The case instead focuses on parental antagonism and disagreement over child rearing as making joint custody inappropriate, not on the specific conduct described in the proposition.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.relevant_excerpt: “However, we agree with the trial judge’s observation that in order for joint custody or shared responsibility to work, both parents must be able mutually ‘to agree on the basic issues in child rearing and want to cooperate in making decisions for [their] children.’ … Although complete agreement between parents to implement joint custody may not be necessary, in order to be effective ‘joint custody requires two capable parents with some degree of respect for one another’s abilities as parents, together with a willingness and ability to work together to reach results on major decisions….’”

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003)..proposition: Additionally, Massachusetts courts emphasize the importance of a child's relationship with both parents. See *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003)..support_reasoning: The opinion’s core analysis is about applying the statutory best‑interests standard and preserving stability with a primary caregiver, not a general policy statement about relationships with both parents. However, the court expressly notes that it is important for the child to spend as much time as possible with her father to foster their close relationship and upholds a custodial arrangement deliberately structured to ensure "continued and substantial involvement with both parents." This provides some support for the proposition that Massachusetts courts emphasize a child’s relationship with both parents, though that is not the principal holding.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003)..relevant_excerpt:
[T]he father is more “attuned” to many of the activities that he and Kali can pursue together when time constraints because of his work schedule and her school do not interfere; and that it is important that Kali be able to spend as much time as possible with her father on weekends, holidays, and during school vacations to continue to foster their close and positive relationship.
...
[The judge] attempted to structure a permanent custodial award to serve the best interests of Kali, including her continued and substantial involvement with both parents.

*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..proposition: Other case law and authority supporting a modification in this scenario include:
*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The claimed proposition is incomplete and only says that the case is cited as “other case law and authority supporting a modification in this scenario.” Schechter is primarily a divorce, custody, 209A, removal, and prenuptial agreement case; it does not address standards for modifying an existing judgment or order in any meaningful way. The opinion mentions that future modification of custody/visitation or removal is possible, but it does not supply a rule or holding about when modification is warranted, so it does not substantively support a proposition about modification standards.
*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: “Despite the judge’s decision documenting the father’s abuse of the mother and concluding that the father’s visitation with the child should be suspended, the judge did not terminate the father’s parental rights, and clearly left open the possibility of a modification of his order precluding visitation. In a case such as this, the father’s constitutional rights as a parent require that the judge considering a request for removal take into account the potential for the father to seek a resumption of visitation.”

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Other case law and authority supporting a modification in this scenario include:
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The proposition fragment—"Other case law and authority supporting a modification in this scenario include"—suggests this case is being cited to show authority supporting a *modification* of custody (presumably to allow relocation). Mason v. Coleman does address modification and relocation in a joint physical custody context, but its holding affirms denial of relocation and continuation of shared custody; it is not authority in favor of granting a modification to permit removal. Thus, while it is relevant relocation/removal authority, it does not substantively support a proposition that other authority favors modification in this scenario.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that in such a situation ‘cause shown’ pursuant to G. L. c. 208, § 30, means a showing that removal is in the ‘best interests’ of the children taking into account all the circumstances and weighing the factors as described below. On the facts in this case, the judge appropriately considered the ‘best interests’ of the children, and did not abuse her discretion in concluding that removal of the children would not serve their best interests…. The judge did not award sole physical custody to either party, deciding instead to order continued shared legal and physical custody.”

*Chasnov v. Chasnov*, 370 Mass. 499 (197.proposition: Other case law and authority supporting a modification in this scenario include:
*Chasnov v. Chasnov*, 370 Mass. 499 (197.support_reasoning: The proposition refers to “other case law and authority supporting a modification in this scenario,” which clearly contemplates domestic relations/modification (likely of a divorce, support, or custody order). The cited opinion is a criminal case involving search and seizure of cocaine and the sufficiency of evidence of knowing possession; it does not concern family law, modifications of prior judgments, or similar issues. Therefore it does not support the proposition for which it is cited.
*Chasnov v. Chasnov*, 370 Mass. 499 (197.relevant_excerpt: “We come finally to the most difficult question in this appeal, the defendant’s contention that the prosecution’s evidence did not warrant a finding that the defendant knew the package contained cocaine. If the defendant is correct, his motion for a directed verdict... should have been allowed because knowing and intentional possession must be proved to establish a violation of G. L. c. 94C, § 32, for possession of a controlled substance with intent to distribute.”

*McMahon v. McMahon*, 31 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Other case law and authority supporting a modification in this scenario include:
*McMahon v. McMahon*, 31 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The proposition refers to “other case law and authority supporting a modification in this scenario,” implying authority about modification of an existing judgment or order. McMahon v. McMahon concerns the trial court’s jurisdiction to divide military retirement pay and the propriety of the original property division under G.L. c. 208, § 34; it does not address modification standards or whether a modification is warranted. Therefore it does not support the proposition as described.
*McMahon v. McMahon*, 31 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “At the time of the divorce, Richard was still in the Air Force. The judge awarded Susan forty-five percent of Richard’s disposable retirement pay and fifty-five percent of the proceeds from the sale of the marital residence… At the time of the judgment, the judge made findings of fact which show that she considered all factors relevant under G. L. c. 208, § 34… We see no abuse of discretion in the judge’s decision…”
